news.title: Remembering Dr Malinga: a voice for Inclusion of the disabled in independent Zim
news.content:
Story by Anashe Murombedzi
AFRICA is home to numerous icons who have excelled in various fields. Among them was Zimbabwe’s late national hero, Dr Joshua Malinga, a relentless advocate for the recognition and inclusion of people with disabilities in the nation’s development.
Dr Malinga did not only champion the rights of persons with disabilities but also fought for their full participation in the fruits of independence—laying a foundation for a more inclusive Zimbabwe.
With a life marked by both hardship and triumph, Dr Malinga’s unwavering determination and passion for justice inspired generations of Zimbabweans and echoed across borders.
Born on 20 April 1944, in rural Filabusi, Matabeleland South Province, his life changed dramatically at the age of two when he contracted polio, resulting in a permanent physical disability.
Yet, rather than allow this to define or limit him, he used it as a platform to drive advocacy for the rights of the disabled.
As a young man, Dr Malinga attended school and learned a craft as a cobbler at Jairos Jiri Centre in Bulawayo.
This foundation would serve him well in his future endeavours, as he became a vocal advocate for the rights and interests of people with disabilities in Zimbabwe and beyond.
Dr Malinga’s entry into politics was sparked by the injustices and oppression faced by black people under the colonial regime.
He joined the nationalist movement, becoming an activist for the liberation struggle, and after independence he rose through the ranks of ZANU PF to become a Central Committee and Politburo member.
Throughout his illustrious career, Dr Malinga was a champion of disability rights, becoming the founding member of the National Council of Disabled Persons of Zimbabwe (NCDPZ) in 1975 and serving as the World President of Disabled Peoples’ International (DPI).
He played a pivotal role in shaping government policies and programmes that addressed the needs and challenges of people with disabilities, and his legacy continues to inspire and empower individuals with disabilities to this day.
Having served as the chairperson of the National Disability Board, Dr Malinga also worked tirelessly during the constitution making process by mobilising disability organisations which went around the country collecting views from the disability constituency and other stakeholders.
The views from the disability sector led to a constitutional provision for the reservation of two senatorial positions for people with disabilities.
His efforts did not go unnoticed after President Emmerson Mnangagwa appointed him Advisor on Disability Issues in the Office of the President and Cabinet.

news.title: Zim to establish Institute of Civil Protection and Disaster Management
news.content:
Story by Kenias Chivuzhe
PLANS are underway for the establishment of the country’s first Institute of Civil Protection and Disaster Management as a resilience measure against climate-induced disasters.
The establishment of the Institute of Civil Protection and Disaster Management is described as a milestone development in the country’s quest to promote excellence in civil protection and emergency management in the face of recurrent disasters affecting the country and the region.
Manicaland State University of Applied Sciences Vice Chancellor Professor Albert Chahwanda whose institution signed an MOU with the city of Mutare spoke on the scope and timeframes in implementing the new initiative.
“This MOU is between the state university and the city of Mutare to establish an institute of civil protection and disaster management. This is the first of its kind in Zimbabwe and in the Southern Africa region. The training will benefit all councils, private companies, timber companies and fuel companies among others.
“The training will be conducted in partnership with the Belarus Civil Protection and Disaster Management University. In the short term, we are going to start with a certificate in disaster and firefighting engineering. Mutare City town Clerk Mr Blessing Chafesuka spoke on the focus of the new initiative.
“We are looking forward to training firefighters who are able to do sea diving and who are able to respond to any type of disaster. We hope this will be a solution for the whole country. The government recently procured firefighting equipment and distributed it to all local authorities. There is now a gap in terms of personnel hence this partnership. As a city for the next 10 years, we are ok in terms of equipment. The challenge has been a mass exodus of personnel overseas and the training of more personnel will create a big buffer,” Mr Chafesuka said.
Government believe the establishment of the civil protection institute in the country was long overdue due to a number of disasters affecting the country.
“The signing of a memorandum of understanding will give birth to the Institute of Civil Protection. The development resonates with the Second Republic’s thrust to strengthen disaster preparedness and improve community-based recovery mechanisms. Manicaland has been greatly affected by cyclones that include Eline and Idai and these experiences taught us valuable lessons therefore we are heartened by this initiative and we will give you our maximum support. news.title: Churches emphasise unity, peace, and hope during Easter
news.content:
Story by Peter Chivhima
CHRISTIAN denominations across Zimbabwe gathered over the Easter weekend to commemorate the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ, using the sacred occasion to promote messages of peace, national unity, and spiritual renewal.
In a vibrant and spirit-filled atmosphere, congregants from various churches convened at multiple venues to mark this pivotal moment in the Christian calendar.
“We are so happy to be here, celebrating the death and resurrection of Jesus. As you can see, we are the youth, and we are full of excitement. We are also taking this opportunity to raise awareness about the dangers of drug and substance abuse,” a youth said.
“During Easter, we celebrate, the death, the burial and the resurrection of Jesus Christ, so we host our youth conference. The youth do everything. The time we are living in now is very dangerous because the enemy is attacking us. So during Easter, we come together and do our projects. So we have different speakers who give us words that are specifically for us and protect us during our youth. It keeps us safe, it keeps us strong, and it keeps us celebrating in the Lord,” a youth participant said.
“We are here celebrating Easter and we are happy that this was organised by our youths. We are taking this opportunity to educate our youths about the dangers of drug and substance abuse,” Pastor Dorcas Jaricha said.
For many, Easter is not only a moment of deep reflection and gratitude, but also a season of renewal, unity, and spiritual awakening.

news.title: Tsvingwe–St Augustine’s bridge repairs near completion
news.content:
Story by Kenias Chivuzhe
THE business community in Penhalonga, Manicaland Province, is set to breathe a sigh of relief as authorities move swiftly to repair the damaged Tsvingwe–St Augustine’s High School Bridge, with completion expected within the next ten days.
The bridge, which collapsed three weeks ago, has long served as a critical link for economic activities in Tsvingwe, connecting residents, schools, and mining operations on both sides of the road.
Its destruction forced vehicles to take lengthy detours, severely affecting business operations and daily commuting.
“This bridge was damaged three weeks ago after being constructed a long time ago. We are happy with the swift action by our local legislator Misheck Mugadza and the government led by President Emmerson Mnangagwa to start reconstruction works. We were now using routes that are very far away to reach our destinations,” community member said,
“We want to thank our legislator Mugadza and President Mnangagwa for moving with speed to reconstruct this bridge.Its damage is causing a lot oftravellinginconveniences,” a traveller said.
“This bridge isvery importantfor everyone as its damage affected the movement of vehicles. The reconstruction works come as good news to residents, especially to our children who were facing challenges crossing on their way to school,” a parent said.
Manicaland Roads Construction Engineer Patrick Muropa says the road will be open for public use after a duration of ten days revealing plans to construct a bigger bridge along the same route which also links St Augustine’s high school.
“As thedepartmentofroads, we have come to repair the bridge using the whole of government approach so that we repair it in a shortperiod of time. Weare going togive the bridge 10 more days after pouring concrete for curing and we are appealing to residents to be patient with us during construction works. The bridge was deformed due tohaveloads and edging. This is a temporary phase and we are also going to construct atwo barrelbridge at the same river course,” Engineer Muropa said.
Mutasa South legislator Advocate Mugadza who is also the Manicaland minister of state for provincial affairs and devolutionalsorevealed the decision to construct a bigger bridge soon after repairing the oldbridge.
“It was now impossible for vehicles to pass through this bridge but because of President Mnangagwa’s whole of government policy, relevant government departments and council among other stakeholders moved in swiftly following this emergency,” he said.

news.title: Rovos rail tourists safely arrive in Victoria Falls after train accident
news.content:
Story by Tichaona Kurewa
INTERNATIONAL tourists who were on board the Rovos Rail train that was involved in an accident near Gwanda this Friday, are now safely in the resort city of Victoria Falls.
The tourists, expressed heartfelt gratitude to the Zimbabwean government and various stakeholders for the support they received after their luxury train was involved in an accident with a goods train in Gwanda this Friday.
Now safely in the iconic resort city, the visitors were in high spirits, eager to enjoy the beauty and attractions of Victoria Falls, despite the unfortunate events earlier in their journey.
“I am a tourist from the United Kingdom. Accidents happen everywhere, and we are just happy to finally be here. We thank everyone for the support. I am looking forward to a lot of fun the weather is lovely today. Victoria Falls is beautiful,” a tourist said.
“I cannot wait to enjoy Victoria Falls. I am happy to be here and sure I will have a great time. I am also excited to try local cuisines,” an international traveller said.
